headline: AI-Generated Art Won a Prize. Artists Aren‚Äôt Happy.

article text:
Artificial IntelligenceMicrosoft‚Äôs Risk-TakerFine Print ChangesQuiz: Fake or Real Images?Apple Enters A.I. FrayMeta‚Äôs A.I. ScrapingAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTSupported bySKIP ADVERTISEMENTThe ShiftAn A.I.-Generated Picture Won an Art Prize. Artists Aren‚Äôt Happy.‚ÄúI won, and I didn‚Äôt break any rules,‚Äù the artwork‚Äôs creator says.Share full article1.5kRead in appJason Allen‚Äôs A.I.-generated work, ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D‚Äôop√©ra Spatial,‚Äù took first place in the digital category at the Colorado State Fair.Credit...via Jason AllenBy Kevin RooseSept. 2, 2022This year, the Colorado State Fair‚Äôs annual art competition gave out prizes in all the usual categories: painting, quilting, sculpture.But one entrant, Jason M. Allen of Pueblo West, Colo., didn‚Äôt make his entry with a brush or a lump of clay. He created it with Midjourney, an artificial intelligence program that turns lines of text into hyper-realistic graphics.Mr. Allen‚Äôs work, ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D‚Äôop√©ra Spatial,‚Äù took home the blue ribbon in the fair‚Äôs contest for emerging digital artists ‚Äî making it one of the first A.I.-generated pieces to win such a prize, and setting off a fierce backlash from artists who accused him of, essentially, cheating.Subscribe to The Times to read as many articles as you like.Kevin Roose is a technology columnist and the author of ‚ÄúFutureproof: 9 Rules for Humans in the Age of Automation.‚Äù More about Kevin RooseA version of this article appears in print on Sept. 3, 2022, Section B, Page 1 of the New York edition with the headline: Creating Art By Typing In Some Words. Order Reprints | Today‚Äôs Paper | SubscribeRead 1523 CommentsShare full article1.5kRead in appAdvertisementSKIP ADVERTISEMENTComments 1523An A.I.-Generated Picture Won an Art Prize. Artists Aren‚Äôt Happy.Skip to CommentsThe comments section is closed.

Title: He used AI to win a fine-arts competition. Was it cheating? - The Washington Post
description: When Jason Allen submitted his ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D‚Äôop√©ra Spatial‚Äù into the Colorado State Fair‚Äôs fine arts competition last week, the sumptuous print was an immediate hit. It also marked a new milestone in the growth of artificial intelligence.

article text: He used AI to win a fine-arts competition. Was it cheating?One judge said the striking piece evoked Renaissance art. But some critics compared it to ‚Äòentering a marathon and driving a Lamborghini to the finish line.‚ÄôJason Allen at the Westgate in Las Vegas. (Mikayla Whitmore)12 min770Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.By  Drew HarwellSeptember 2, 2022 at 11:08 a.m. EDTWhen Jason Allen submitted his ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D‚Äôop√©ra Spatial‚Äù into the Colorado State Fair‚Äôs fine arts competition last week, the sumptuous print was an immediate hit, beating 20 other artists in the ‚Äúdigitally manipulated photography‚Äù category to win the first-place blue ribbon and a $300 prize.What Allen had only hinted at, however, was that the artwork had been created in large part by an artificial-intelligence tool, Midjourney, that can generate realistic images at a user‚Äôs command. The portrait of three figures, dressed in flowing robes, staring out to a bright beyond, was so finely detailed the judges couldn‚Äôt tell.AdvertisementStory continues below advertisementAllen‚Äôs piece offers a clear example of how rapidly AI-generated art has advanced. Trained on billions of internet images, the systems have decisively pushed the boundaries of what computers can create.But it has also sparked a massive debate over the meaning of art, with Allen facing accusations that he had been deceptive in beating out other human artists with something he asked a machine to create.Text-to-image tools like DALL-E 2 and Midjourney have quickly increased in sophistication and become one of the hottest topics in AI. They can generate not just fake people, objects and locations but mimic entire visual styles. Users can demand the art piece look like a cartoon storybook or a historical diagram or an Associated Press photograph, and the system will do its best to oblige.But AI-generated art has been criticized as automated plagiarism, because it relies on millions of ingested art pieces that are then parroted en masse. It has also fueled deeper fears: of decimating people‚Äôs creative work, blurring the boundaries of reality or smothering human art.Allen said his art piece shows people need to ‚Äúget past their denial and fear‚Äù of a technology that could empower new inventions and reshape our world. The AI, he said, ‚Äúis a tool, just like the paintbrush is a tool. Without the person, there is no creative force.‚ÄùüíªFollow TechnologyFollowBut he also struck a note of defiance at the critics he believed did not appreciate the profound message in his AI-generated art.‚ÄúYou said AI would never be as good as you, that AI would never do the work you do, and I said, ‚ÄòOh really? How about this? I won,‚Äô‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs here now. Recognize it. Stop denying the reality. AI isn‚Äôt going away.‚Äù***Allen, 39, lives south of his hometown of Colorado Springs and runs a company, Incarnate Games, that makes tabletop fantasy games. He went into the Air Force after high school and got a computer science degree at a Colorado technical school. He does not consider himself an artist and had never entered an arts competition before.Earlier this year, he said, he started noticing people posting more AI art on social media, but he had been initially skeptical to try it himself due to ‚Äúspiritual reasons.‚Äù Elon Musk, he remembered, had compared AI to ‚Äúsummoning the demon,‚Äù and the practice felt like it could be ‚Äúa gateway into communicating with the unknown.‚Äù‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what it feels like. This isn‚Äôt being created by a human,‚Äù Allen said Thursday while watching a jiujitsu tournament in Las Vegas. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot to be said about the spiritual meddling of our reality. They would use anything they could to influence humanity.‚ÄùBut the art was just so intricate, he said, that he couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about it. He started playing with AI-powered art tools: WOMBO Dream, NightCafe, starryai. Then, someone invited him to Midjourney, and he became obsessed.The Google engineer who thinks the company‚Äôs AI has come to lifeMidjourney has become one of the most popular AI art generators largely because it allows anyone to freely create new images on command. Using the prompt ‚Äú/imagine,‚Äù a user can type in whatever they want to see and the AI will return four newly created images in 60 seconds. The user can also ask the AI to improve, or ‚Äúupscale,‚Äù the visual quality with new variations on the same idea.The start-up, which calls itself ‚Äúan independent research lab ‚Ä¶ expanding the imaginative powers of the human species,‚Äù operates largely out of a 1-million-follower network on the chat service Discord, with rooms devoted to character creation, environments and ‚Äúshow and tell.‚ÄùAfter paying for a corporate account, Allen started generating thousands of images, changing the text prompts with every creation. He experimented with new settings, scenarios and effects. He asked for images in the styles of Leonardo da Vinci and the American psychedelic artist Alex Grey.AdvertisementStory continues below advertisementThe pieces that really caught his attention, though, were what he now calls his ‚Äúspace opera theater‚Äù series. He started with a simple mental image ‚Äî ‚Äúa woman in a Victorian frilly dress, wearing a space helmet‚Äù ‚Äî and kept fine-tuning the prompts, ‚Äúusing tests to really make an epic scene, like out of a dream.‚Äù He said he spent 80 hours making more than 900 iterations of the art, adding words like ‚Äúopulent‚Äù and ‚Äúlavish‚Äù to fine tune its tone and feel. He declined to share the full series of words he used to create his art, saying it is his artistic product, and that he intends to publish it later. ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs one thing you can take ownership of, it‚Äôs your prompt,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúI was like: Dude,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is so sick! I want to see more of it! I‚Äôm addicted! I‚Äôm obsessed!‚ÄùWhen he found images he really liked, he pulled them into Adobe Photoshop to remove visual artifacts. In one image, the central figure was missing a head, so he also painted in a crop of dark, wavy hair. He used another machine-learning tool, Gigapixel AI, to increase the photos‚Äô quality and sharpness, then printed the three pieces on canvas ‚Äî all variations on the French phrase for ‚Äúspace opera theater,‚Äù which he thought sounded cool ‚Äî and drove to submit them to the state fair.When he looked at the pieces, he said, he saw ‚Äúa supernatural reality ‚Ä¶ something we haven‚Äôt even been able to experience yet, past the great beyond.‚Äù But the pace of AI art is moving perhaps even faster than the internet. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre looking at art from a month ago,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIn technology terms, that‚Äôs decades. This piece is antiquated compared to what Midjourney is doing now.‚Äù***The state fair in Pueblo, Colo., was an unlikely place for the writing of a new chapter in art history. The 150-year-old festival, known for its horse and livestock competitions, runs a series of more traditional art competitions, including for homemade dolls, quilts, porcelain art and needlework, as well as for the best canned carrots, medicinal remedies and holiday breads.Of the 596 entries in the ‚Äúfine arts‚Äù competition, 21 amateur ‚Äúemerging artists‚Äù submitted pieces of ‚Äúdigitally manipulated photography,‚Äù one of the fair‚Äôs newest categories. Asked what art materials he had used, Allen told state fair officials only that he used Midjourney ‚Äî though he did not exactly go into detail, and no one seems to have asked.One of the judges, Dagny McKinley, an author and art historian who runs a playwright festival in nearby Steamboat Springs, remembers walking past Allen‚Äôs canvas and being immediately drawn to a piece that felt reminiscent of Renaissance art.‚ÄúIt had an immediate story: People looking out into another world, everyone with their backs to you, no one facing or engaging with the viewers,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou get interested: What are they seeing?‚ÄùMcKinley said she did not realize the art was AI-generated but said it wouldn‚Äôt have changed her judgment anyway; Allen, she said, ‚Äúhad a concept and a vision he brought to reality, and it‚Äôs really a beautiful piece.‚ÄùAdvertisementStory continues below advertisementSebastian Smee, The Washington Post‚Äôs art critic, said the piece‚Äôs textures and lighting are reminiscent of Gustave Moreau, a late 19th-century artist, associated with the Decadents, who influenced Edgar Degas and Henri Matisse. (He also recalled a quote from the artist Sol LeWitt, who said, ‚ÄúThe idea becomes a machine that makes the art.‚Äù)When Allen announced his victory himself on Midjourney‚Äôs Discord channel, saying he had spent ‚Äúmany weeks of fine tuning and curating,‚Äù the responses spiraled between muted excitement to outright dread. In a chat board devoted to philosophical debates, one user compared the win to ‚Äúentering a marathon and driving a Lamborghini to the finish line.‚Äù Another user wrote that the ‚Äústunt‚Äù threatened to ‚Äúget this tool banned and hated even more.‚ÄùReady or not, mass video deepfakes are comingThe win also triggered a flood of rage online. A tweet expressing profane dismay at Allen‚Äôs win has been liked more than 85,000 times. Another person tweeted, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre watching the death of artistry unfold right before our eyes.‚Äù Allen said he has also gotten ‚Äúa lot of very nasty hate‚Äù in his online inboxes; on his game company‚Äôs Instagram profile, one user said he should return his award and ‚Äúpost a public apology before some MAJOR backlash comes your way.‚ÄùSome of the frustration has come from how the tools were built: a similar tool, Stable Diffusion, was ‚Äútrained‚Äù on 2 billion images taken from the internet, including from personal blogs and amateur-art sites like Flickr and DeviantArt.Allen, however, dismisses the point as shallow: ‚ÄúWhere did you learn how to do your art? You looked at art. Whose art was it? You learned their techniques, you studied their art, you added it to your repertoire,‚Äù he said.Allen listed the pieces for $750 each, he said, and two were sold at the fair to unknown buyers, though he now frets that he should have charged far more, given that it could be ‚Äúessentially a piece of art history.‚Äù On Discord, some users asked whether he should have been more explicit, to which Allen replied: ‚ÄúDid I have to?‚ÄùDespite the online furor, Allen‚Äôs neighbors seemed more sanguine about adapting to AI. As far as anyone at the Colorado Department of Agriculture can tell, Allen did not break any rules. Pieces for the category are only required to involve ‚Äútechnology as part of the creative or presentation process.‚Äù Digital filters, color-manipulation tools and the ‚Äúrecombination of images‚Äù are all expressly allowed.No one has filed an official grievance over the result, either, department spokeswoman Olga Robak said, though there has been an unrelated dispute in the fair‚Äôs goat-shearing contest.Robak, who studied art history, finds the controversy fascinating. ‚ÄúPeople put bananas on the wall and called it art,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúEven photography was not considered an art form for a long time; people said it was just pushing a button, and now we realize it‚Äôs about composition, color, light. Who are we to say that AI is not the same way?‚ÄùDon‚Äôt ask if the duct-tape banana is art. Ask if it‚Äôs any good.***Jessica Hair, a 25-year-old receptionist at a doctor‚Äôs office who won third place in the competition, said she did not feel Allen had acted unfairly and had no hard feelings about his win.Hair said her ‚ÄúJudge, Jury, Executioner,‚Äù which depicts a tuxedoed skeleton on a golden throne surrounded by skulls, took 15 hours to create with a stylus on an iPad Pro. But Allen‚Äôs piece took time, effort and subjective judgment, too, and ‚Äúhow do we qualify what is and isn‚Äôt art?‚Äù she said.She did wonder, though, if it might have broken the fair‚Äôs rules requiring all art to have been made by Colorado residents. Would the AI, wherever it exists, qualify?McKinley, the contest judge, said she understands the frustrations from some artists feeling spurned in their craft, and she believes the festival should consider a category purely devoted to AI art. But she sees such technology as opening up a new world of possibilities for artists ‚Äî and as something it‚Äôd be better to embrace, since it isn‚Äôt going away.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to take away from a beautiful painting or a sculpture you can touch,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just one more tool we have to advance what we can create.‚ÄùAdvertisementStory continues below advertisementGregory Block, an oil painter in Denver who was not a part of the competition, said he finds it hard to imagine an AI generator supplanting the hundreds of hours ‚Äî and all the ‚Äúheart, soul, blood, sweat and tears‚Äù ‚Äî he‚Äôs invested into his art. But he also thinks back to the artists that first inspired him, who used rudimentary devices like the camera lucida, in the 1800s, to aid their own designs.‚ÄúThat was thought of as cheating, too,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYet they used it to make these incredible paintings: anatomically correct figures, beautiful soft lighting. ‚Ä¶ Those steps in technology are elemental to our art. Otherwise, we‚Äôd still be doing cave paintings with just our hands and blood.‚ÄùThe AI, he said, can imbue the art with a mysterious beauty, made all the more special because it is so hard to understand. But ‚Äúthe soul any of us can find in a piece of artwork, the emotion, the human struggle we identify with in art is always our own.‚Äù‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt have to necessarily be created out of a human soul, the artwork itself. It is for us to see and react to,‚Äù Block said. ‚ÄúWe the viewers are, in the end, the ultimate artists. We‚Äôre the ones creating the world that is coming in through our eyeballs. That world is in our mind.‚ÄùNitasha Tiku contributed to this report.Share770 Comments

Title: US blocks sales of some AI chips to China as tech crackdown intensifies - The Guardian
description: Ban on Nvidia and AMD sales marks a major escalation of US efforts to restrict China‚Äôs military technology capabilities as tensions bubble over Taiwan
og:description: Ban on Nvidia and AMD sales marks a major escalation of US efforts to restrict China‚Äôs military technology capabilities as tensions bubble over Taiwan
article text:
US officials have ordered Nvidia and AMD to stop exporting some computing chips for artificial intelligence work to China. Photograph: Tyrone Siu/ReutersView image in fullscreenUS officials have ordered Nvidia and AMD to stop exporting some computing chips for artificial intelligence work to China. Photograph: Tyrone Siu/ReutersChina This article is more than 1 year oldUS blocks sales of some AI chips to China as tech crackdown intensifiesThis article is more than 1 year oldBan on Nvidia and AMD sales marks a major escalation of US efforts to restrict China‚Äôs military technology capabilities as tensions bubble over TaiwanReutersThu 1 Sep 2022 00.46 EDTLast modified on Thu 1 Sep 2022 01.15 EDTShareChip designer Nvidia said that US officials told it to stop exporting two top computing chips for artificial intelligence work to China, a move that could cripple Chinese firms‚Äô ability to carry out advanced work like image recognition.The company on Wednesday said the ban, which affects its A100 and H100 chips designed to speed up machine learning tasks, could interfere with completion of developing the H100, the flagship chip Nvidia announced this year.Nvidia said US officials told it the new rule ‚Äúwill address the risk that the covered products may be used in, or diverted to, a ‚Äòmilitary end use‚Äô or ‚Äòmilitary end user‚Äô in China.‚ÄùAsked for comment, the US department of Commerce would not say what new criteria it has laid out for AI chips that can no longer be shipped to China but said it is reviewing its China-related policies and practices ‚Äúkeep advanced technologies out of the wrong hands.Huawei founder sparks alarm in China with warning of ‚Äòpainful‚Äô next decadeRead more‚ÄúWhile we are not in a position to outline specific policy changes at this time, we are taking a comprehensive approach to implement additional actions necessary related to technologies, end-uses, and end-users to protect US national security and foreign policy interests,‚Äù a spokesperson told Reuters.The announcement signals a major escalation of the US crackdown on China‚Äôs technological capabilities as tensions bubble over the fate of Taiwan, where chips for Nvidia and almost every other major chip firm are manufactured.A spokesperson for rival AMD told Reuters the company had received new license requirements that will stop its MI250 artificial intelligence chips from being exported to China, but it believes its MI100 chips will not be affected. 
 Without American chips from companies such as Nvidia and AMD, Chinese organisations will be unable to cost-effectively carry out the kind of advanced computing used for image and speech recognition, among many other tasks.Image recognition and natural language processing are common in consumer applications like smartphones that can answer queries and tag photos. They also have military uses such as scouring satellite imagery for weapons or bases and filtering digital communications for intelligence-gathering purposes.Nvidia said it had booked $400m in sales of the affected chips this quarter to China that could be lost if Chinese firms decide not to buy alternative Nvidia products. It said it plans to apply for exemptions to the rule but has ‚Äúno assurances‚Äù that US officials will grant them.Explore more on these topicsChinaAsia PacificUS foreign policynewsShareReuse this contentMost viewedDonald Trump‚Äôs run of good luck could end this weekend ‚Äì if Joe Biden does the right thingJonathan FreedlandLiveMore Democrats call for Biden to exit 2024 race as president vows to return to campaign trail ‚Äì liveJapan asks young people why they are not marrying amid population crisisLiveWindows IT outage live: CrowdStrike CEO ‚Äòdeeply sorry‚Äô for global chaos caused by update and warns fix may take time to workMicrosoft Windows IT outage: more than 2,000 flights canceled across US; Fedex and UPS report service delays ‚Äì as it happened

Title: The researchers using AI to analyse peer review - Nature.com
description: Anna Severin explains how her team used machine learning to try to assess the quality of thousands of reviewers‚Äô reports.

article text:
NEWS Q&A
01 September 2022

The researchers using AI to analyse peer review


                    Anna Severin explains how her team used machine learning to try to assess the quality of thousands of reviewers‚Äô reports.
                




    By
    
        
        
                Richard Van Noorden




Richard Van Noorden


View author publications

You can also search for this author in PubMed
¬†Google Scholar

Access through your institution




Buy or subscribe




Do more-highly cited journals have higher-quality peer review? Reviews are generally confidential and the definition of ‚Äòquality‚Äô is elusive, so this is a difficult question to answer. But researchers who used machine learning to study 10,000 peer-review reports in biomedical journals have tried. They invented proxy measures for quality, which they term thoroughness and helpfulness.

Title: Don‚Äôt let the robot discard your resume: Applying for work in an automated world - EL PA√çS USA
description: Many companies use artificial intelligence systems to screen CVs. Here‚Äôs how to avoid their biases and exploit their weaknesses
og:description: Many companies use artificial intelligence systems to screen CVs. Here‚Äôs how to avoid their biases and exploit their weaknesses
mainEntityOfPage: {'@type': ['WebPage', 'ItemPage'], '@id': 'https://english.elpais.com/science-tech/2022-09-05/dont-let-the-robot-discard-your-resume-applying-for-work-in-an-automated-world.html', 'name': 'Don‚Äôt let the robot discard your resume: Applying for work in an automated world'}
author: [{'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Patricia Coll Rubio', 'url': 'https://english.elpais.com/author/patricia-coll-rubio/'}]
headline: Don‚Äôt let the robot discard your resume: Applying for work in an automated world
article text: SCIENCEDon‚Äôt let the robot discard your resume: Applying for work in an automated worldMany companies use artificial intelligence systems to screen CVs. Here‚Äôs how to avoid their biases and exploit their weaknessesMost large companies now use artificial intelligence to screen and discard resumes.Hispanolistic (Getty Images)Patricia Coll RubioSEP 05, 2022 - 00:19 EDTWhatsappFacebookTwitterLinkedinCopy linkCompany hiring managers are integrating artificial intelligence (AI) systems to automate decisions on job applicants. ‚ÄúJob candidates are often unaware of these methods,‚Äù warns Cristina Colom, director of Digital Future Society, an agency from Spain that informs citizens about technology issues.Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) are one of the most widely used types of software in the human resources field. They offer specific solutions for recruiting personnel and cull applications ‚Äúto leave a manageable number of resumes that meet a position‚Äôs requirements,‚Äù explains Carme Rosell√≥, the coordinator of labor market projects at Barcelona Activa.First and foremost, automation allows for ‚Äúfast screening,‚Äù says recruitment consultant Juan Gonzalez. Softgarden, the company he works for, currently processes 2 million applications a year for 40,000 recruiters. ‚ÄúThere are companies that receive 400 candidates for one position. If you‚Äôre hiring for four jobs, how could you sift through 1,200 candidates at once?‚Äù he asks.Technologies like Softgarden, a Software as a Service (SaaS) system that allows candidates and companies to connect to applications installed in the cloud, ‚Äústreamline tasks, accomplishing in 30 minutes what used to take two hours,‚Äù says Gonz√°lez. He also points out the importance of ‚Äúrespecting the digital rights‚Äù set forth in European data protection regulations.One must ‚Äúmake sure that the resume includes the position‚Äôs keywords, because the algorithm works like a dictionary‚ÄùThe system ‚Äúuses artificial intelligence to automatically collect data [by] searching for keywords in the text,‚Äù Gonz√°lez notes. That‚Äôs why he recommends that candidates use a ‚Äútextual resume, without columns or graphics, that have a simple format and list experience, education and languages in reverse chronological order. Applicants should avoid symbols, illustrations and diagrams because creativity works against us in ATS searches. The resume should be simple and use standard fonts like Arial or Verdana because machines don‚Äôt read them all equally well,‚Äù Rosell√≥ adds.One must ‚Äúmake sure that the position‚Äôs keywords appear on the resume, because the algorithm works like a dictionary to match different descriptions,‚Äù advises Jaume Alemany, the co-founder of the Etalentum recruitment company. His company just invested $497,650 to create the Robinson system, ‚Äúa robot that can manage millions of data [bytes] and reduces the risk of automated discards.‚ÄùKeywords and employee proximityRobinson‚Äôs algorithm is ‚Äúbased on information from more than 3,000 recruitment processes, so its learning system identifies the variables that companies consider most important. Even with the rise in telecommuting since the pandemic,‚Äù the first concern is employee proximity, Etalentum‚Äôs co-founder says. ‚ÄúAlthough it sounds ridiculous, it‚Äôs important to indicate the city where you live and where you want to work, if they‚Äôre not the same. For example, if you say that you work in [Los Angeles], but you want to move to [New York City] or take a job there, include the latter city, because otherwise the machine will discard your resume,‚Äù Softgarden consultant Juan Gonz√°lez notes.Language can also be an important factor to bear in mind. ‚ÄúDepending on the position you‚Äôre applying for, it‚Äôs [generally] advisable to write your resume in two or three languages, especially in English, because there are machines that are better trained to read [that language],‚Äù Alemany points out.Because ‚Äúrecruitment processes are increasingly automated, especially when applications are initially received and screened, we need to personalize and optimize [our] resumes according to the job description and emphasize the information that‚Äôs most relevant to the position,‚Äù says Nilton Navarro, the brand manager at Infojobs.Carme Rosell√≥ notes that it‚Äôs essential for ‚Äúa resume to contain the position‚Äôs keywords.‚Äù For that reason, she recommends researching the qualities that companies, or robots in this case, are seeking for a given position. ‚ÄúThere are many ways to search for keywords,‚Äù she says. The most basic way is to analyze the terminology that companies use and find information about similar job profiles on networks like LinkedIn.To make sure that your resume isn‚Äôt discarded even though you meet the job requirements, you can avail yourself of tools such as Resume Worded or Zipjob. They let you ‚Äúupload your resume to perform a scan and see if it would pass the ATS filter,‚Äù Rosell√≥ says. She also mentions Google‚Äôs ‚Äúvery interesting‚Äù Interview Warmup, which is ‚Äúa key interview training tool that gives you information about the words used most frequently in the sector you‚Äôre targeting‚Äù; she says using it is ‚Äúa great practice.‚Äù The expert insists that it‚Äôs important to ‚Äústay up to date‚Äù on these tricks, because ‚Äútechnology advances very quickly.‚Äù She notes that it‚Äôs unfortunate that automated systems sometimes discard ‚Äúgood candidates‚Äù because of ‚Äúsomething outside [the applicants‚Äô] control.‚ÄùThe risk of algorithm biasThe proliferation of smart technology and automated decision systems ‚Äúcan jeopardize some working people‚Äôs fundamental rights and increase the risk of discrimination based on gender, race, sexual orientation, religion or simply personal tastes ... that has an impact that goes beyond the digital world and can widen the social gap, especially among more vulnerable groups,‚Äù warns Digital Future Society‚Äôs director Cristina Colom.However, she notes that ‚Äúcompanies‚Äô use of algorithms and artificial intelligence is here to stay, so the solution isn‚Äôt to eliminate the technology but to better control how it‚Äôs used and ensure that it protects labor rights and equal opportunities to workplace access.‚ÄùColom says that it‚Äôs important to practice ‚Äútechnological humanism‚Äù from the get-go in designing these digital solutions. She advocates ‚Äúintegrating different visions to create them, with greater diversity in the design and programming teams in terms of gender, race and religion, as well as by discipline, broadening them to include areas such as psychology, anthropology and sociology, to ensure that the sources that feed AI aren‚Äôt biased.‚Äù Finally, she emphasizes that ‚Äútechnology can help us to be more efficient and effective, but it can never fully replace people.‚ÄùTu suscripci√≥n se est√° usando en otro dispositivo¬øQuieres a√±adir otro usuario a tu suscripci√≥n?A√±adir usuarioContinuar leyendo aqu√≠Si contin√∫as leyendo en este dispositivo, no se podr√° leer en el otro.¬øPor qu√© est√°s viendo esto?Flecha Tu suscripci√≥n se est√° usando en otro dispositivo y solo puedes acceder a EL PA√çS desde un dispositivo a la vez. Si quieres compartir tu cuenta, cambia tu suscripci√≥n a la modalidad Premium, as√≠ podr√°s a√±adir otro usuario. Cada uno acceder√° con su propia cuenta de email, lo que os permitir√° personalizar vuestra experiencia en EL PA√çS.En el caso de no saber qui√©n est√° usando tu cuenta, te recomendamos cambiar tu contrase√±a aqu√≠.Si decides continuar compartiendo tu cuenta, este mensaje se mostrar√° en tu dispositivo y en el de la otra persona que est√° usando tu cuenta de forma indefinida, afectando a tu experiencia de lectura. Puedes consultar aqu√≠ los t√©rminos y condiciones de la suscripci√≥n digital.More informationNew advance in brain-machine interfaces: Artificial neurons command Venus flytrap to snap shutJavier SalasThe economics of artificial intelligence√Ångel UbideAdheres toMore informationIf you are interested in licensing this content, please contact ventacontenidos@prisamedia.com_newsletterSign up to EL PA√çS US Edition bulletinAp√∫ntateMost viewedFentanyl and scams against American tourists place the Jalisco New Generation Cartel in Washington‚Äôs sightsPorno, anxieties and inches: What makes a man lie about the size of his penis?More mysterious than Neanderthals, the Denisovans hold the key to humanityHulk Hogan at 70: the scandal-plagued wrestler finally finds peaceMelania Trump‚Äôs discreet role at the Republican convention eight years after plagiarizing Michelle Obama
articleBody: Company hiring managers are integrating artificial intelligence (AI) systems to automate decisions on job applicants. ‚ÄúJob candidates are often unaware of these methods,‚Äù warns Cristina Colom, director of Digital Future Society, an agency from Spain that informs citizens about technology issues. Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) are one of the most widely used types of software in the human resources field. They offer specific solutions for recruiting personnel and cull applications ‚Äúto leave a manageable number of resumes that meet a position‚Äôs requirements,‚Äù explains Carme Rosell√≥, the coordinator of labor market projects at Barcelona Activa. First and foremost, automation allows for ‚Äúfast screening,‚Äù says recruitment consultant Juan Gonzalez. Softgarden, the company he works for, currently processes 2 million applications a year for 40,000 recruiters. ‚ÄúThere are companies that receive 400 candidates for one position. If you‚Äôre hiring for four jobs, how could you sift through 1,200 candidates at once?‚Äù he asks. Technologies like Softgarden, a Software as a Service (SaaS) system that allows candidates and companies to connect to applications installed in the cloud, ‚Äústreamline tasks, accomplishing in 30 minutes what used to take two hours,‚Äù says Gonz√°lez. He also points out the importance of ‚Äúrespecting the digital rights‚Äù set forth in European data protection regulations. The system ‚Äúuses artificial intelligence to automatically collect data [by] searching for keywords in the text,‚Äù Gonz√°lez notes. That‚Äôs why he recommends that candidates use a ‚Äútextual resume, without columns or graphics, that have a simple format and list experience, education and languages in reverse chronological order. Applicants should avoid symbols, illustrations and diagrams because creativity works against us in ATS searches. The resume should be simple and use standard fonts like Arial or Verdana because machines don‚Äôt read them all equally well,‚Äù Rosell√≥ adds. One must ‚Äúmake sure that the position‚Äôs keywords appear on the resume, because the algorithm works like a dictionary to match different descriptions,‚Äù advises Jaume Alemany, the co-founder of the Etalentum recruitment company. His company just invested $497,650 to create the Robinson system, ‚Äúa robot that can manage millions of data [bytes] and reduces the risk of automated discards.‚Äù Robinson‚Äôs algorithm is ‚Äúbased on information from more than 3,000 recruitment processes, so its learning system identifies the variables that companies consider most important. Even with the rise in telecommuting since the pandemic,‚Äù the first concern is employee proximity, Etalentum‚Äôs co-founder says. ‚ÄúAlthough it sounds ridiculous, it‚Äôs important to indicate the city where you live and where you want to work, if they‚Äôre not the same. For example, if you say that you work in [Los Angeles], but you want to move to [New York City] or take a job there, include the latter city, because otherwise the machine will discard your resume,‚Äù Softgarden consultant Juan Gonz√°lez notes. Language can also be an important factor to bear in mind. ‚ÄúDepending on the position you‚Äôre applying for, it‚Äôs [generally] advisable to write your resume in two or three languages, especially in English, because there are machines that are better trained to read [that language],‚Äù Alemany points out. Because ‚Äúrecruitment processes are increasingly automated, especially when applications are initially received and screened, we need to personalize and optimize [our] resumes according to the job description and emphasize the information that‚Äôs most relevant to the position,‚Äù says Nilton Navarro, the brand manager at Infojobs. Carme Rosell√≥ notes that it‚Äôs essential for ‚Äúa resume to contain the position‚Äôs keywords.‚Äù For that reason, she recommends researching the qualities that companies, or robots in this case, are seeking for a given position. ‚ÄúThere are many ways to search for keywords,‚Äù she says. The most basic way is to analyze the terminology that companies use and find information about similar job profiles on networks like LinkedIn. To make sure that your resume isn‚Äôt discarded even though you meet the job requirements, you can avail yourself of tools such as Resume Worded or Zipjob. They let you ‚Äúupload your resume to perform a scan and see if it would pass the ATS filter,‚Äù Rosell√≥ says. She also mentions Google‚Äôs ‚Äúvery interesting‚Äù Interview Warmup, which is ‚Äúa key interview training tool that gives you information about the words used most frequently in the sector you‚Äôre targeting‚Äù; she says using it is ‚Äúa great practice.‚Äù The expert insists that it‚Äôs important to ‚Äústay up to date‚Äù on these tricks, because ‚Äútechnology advances very quickly.‚Äù She notes that it‚Äôs unfortunate that automated systems sometimes discard ‚Äúgood candidates‚Äù because of ‚Äúsomething outside [the applicants‚Äô] control.‚Äù The proliferation of smart technology and automated decision systems ‚Äúcan jeopardize some working people‚Äôs fundamental rights and increase the risk of discrimination based on gender, race, sexual orientation, religion or simply personal tastes ... that has an impact that goes beyond the digital world and can widen the social gap, especially among more vulnerable groups,‚Äù warns Digital Future Society‚Äôs director Cristina Colom. However, she notes that ‚Äúcompanies‚Äô use of algorithms and artificial intelligence is here to stay, so the solution isn‚Äôt to eliminate the technology but to better control how it‚Äôs used and ensure that it protects labor rights and equal opportunities to workplace access.‚Äù Colom says that it‚Äôs important to practice ‚Äútechnological humanism‚Äù from the get-go in designing these digital solutions. She advocates ‚Äúintegrating different visions to create them, with greater diversity in the design and programming teams in terms of gender, race and religion, as well as by discipline, broadening them to include areas such as psychology, anthropology and sociology, to ensure that the sources that feed AI aren‚Äôt biased.‚Äù Finally, she emphasizes that ‚Äútechnology can help us to be more efficient and effective, but it can never fully replace people.‚Äù

Title: Economic Development Administration Awards Georgia Tech $65 Million for AI Manufacturing Project | News Center - Georgia Tech News Center
description: The Georgia Institute of Technology has been awarded a $65 million grant from the U.S. Department of Commerce‚Äôs Economic Development Administration (EDA) to support a statewide initiative that combines artificial intelligence and manufacturing innovations with transformational workforce and outreach programs. The grant will increase job and wage opportunities in distressed and rural communities, as well as among historically underrepresented and underserved groups.

Title: SA to establish Artificial Intelligence Institute | SAnews - South African Government News Agency
description: South Africa intends to enhance the teaching of robotics and coding in public
og:description: South Africa intends to enhance the teaching of robotics and coding in public schools through the establishment of an Artificial Intelligence (AI) Institute.
article text:
Thursday, September 1, 2022

 


South Africa intends to enhance the teaching of robotics and coding in public schools through the establishment of an Artificial Intelligence (AI) Institute.
Minister of Communications and Digital Technologies Khumbudzo Ntshavheni said the AI Institute is being established in partnership with institutions of higher learning, in particular the Johannesburg Business School of the University of Johannesburg and the Tshwane University of Technology, which are co-founder institutions together with the Department of Communications and Digital Technologies.
‚ÄúIt is essential that we invest significantly to provide our youth with access to modern training, skill sets and formal education. To achieve this, our Department of Basic Education has introduced robotics and coding as school subjects in primary and high schools.
‚ÄúAt present, learners in over a 1¬†000 schools are designing and producing robots both for gaming and to complete tasks the learners find tedious for human completion.
‚ÄúNext year, learners in these and additional schools that will join this category will compete in a National Robotics Development Challenge,‚Äù the Minister said on Thursday during the G20 Digital Economy Ministers Meeting in Bali, Indonesia.
Government‚Äôs focus on digital skills includes creating platforms to support and promote the ability of the youth, and small and medium enterprises, in particular start-ups to develop digital content.
‚ÄúIn this regard, South Africa will launch an App Store to be known as DigiTech on the 13 September 2022. We have undertaken to our sister countries within Africa to ensure that content producers from the rest of the Africa can have their Apps enrolled on the DigiTech App Store,‚Äù the Minister said.
Bridging the digital divide
With technology changing how people work and live, Ntshavheni said governments have the responsibility to continue to use technology as a primary catalyst for change in the world that should advance accessible public services, inclusive growth, and sustainable development.
She noted that the COVID-19 pandemic exposed the negative impact of the digital divide in human development in particular the poor.
‚ÄúIn South Africa and the majority of the developing world, in particular in Africa, where the poor remained unconnected, the poor were severely marginalised during the COVID-19 pandemic because they were excluded from accessing basic services such as education, health and ability to work.
‚ÄúIt is for this reason that we prioritised and concluded the licensing of the high demand spectrum and also secured the commitment of our telecommunications regulator to ensure that the Frequency Spectrum licence holders contribute towards the national broadband penetration objectives by connecting key public institutions such as schools, health facilities, and traditional authorities.
‚ÄúIn addition, this year we will finalise the roadmap towards the deployment of 4G and 5G networks including to rural towns. We continue to work to attain the objectives of our South Africa Connect programme to ensure that we attain universal access to the internet by 2024,‚Äù the Minister said.
Government is also extending email addresses to all learners/students in public schools and their parents as part of requirements of basic e-learning. ‚Äì SAnews.gov.za


Share this post:

Title: How an AI-generated artwork won the top prize in a US art competition - The Indian Express
description: The winner, Jason Allen, is president of Colorado-based tabletop gaming company Incarnate Games. He won in the digital art category with a work called ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D'op√©ra Spatial‚Äù or ‚ÄòSpace Opera Theater‚Äô.

headline: How an AI-generated artwork won the top prize in a US art competition
name: ['Home', 'Subscribe', 'India News', 'Cities', 'Videos', 'Audio', 'Explained', 'Education', 'Political Pulse', 'Opinion', 'Entertainment', 'Investigations', 'Lifestyle', 'Technology', 'Sports', 'Express Premium', 'Latest News', 'World News', 'Trending', 'Photos', 'Elections 2023', 'Web Stories', 'Bollywood', 'Cricket', 'Science', 'Business', 'Horoscope', 'Delhi News', 'Mumbai News', 'Hyderabad News', 'Bengaluru News', 'What Is', 'When Is', 'Who Is', 'How To', "Today's Paper", 'Brand Solutions']
articleBody: A 39-year-old last week won the top prize at the Colorado State Fair‚Äôs fine art competition for work that he created using artificial intelligence (AI). While the development has reignited the fierce debate over AI in art, the man behind the artwork is unfazed. Amid criticism, he told The New York Times, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to apologise for it‚Ä¶I won, and I didn‚Äôt break any rules.‚Äù Artwork and the winner The winner, Jason Allen, is president of Colorado-based tabletop gaming company Incarnate Games. He won in the digital art category with a work called ‚ÄúTh√©√¢tre D'op√©ra Spatial‚Äù or ‚ÄòSpace Opera Theater‚Äô. As the title suggests, the artwork depicts a space setting with figures in robes looking out through a viewport. The work brings together space opera and classical Baroque elements. How was the artwork created? It was created using Midjourney, which is an AI software that converts text prompts into visual images. The beta version of the software was available from July 2022 and it has allowed users with no training in art to create highly detailed artworks. Critics of AI-generated art, such as this one, argue that converting prompts into art is like painting-by-numbers, which means that there is no real artistry or skill involved. Midjourney, in a matter of minutes, can create a digital artwork that would ordinarily take hours, if not days. ‚ÄúUsers type a series of words in a message to Midjourney; the bot spits back an image seconds later,‚Äù The NYT noted. AI threat to art? After Allen‚Äôs post about his award-winning artwork made it to Twitter, it was met with severe backlash. ‚ÄúThis is so gross,‚Äù a user wrote. ‚ÄúI can see how AI art can be beneficial, but claiming you‚Äôre an artist by generating one? Absolutely not.‚Äù Yet another tweet went, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre watching the death of artistry unfold before our eyes ‚Äî if creative jobs aren‚Äôt safe from machines, then even high-skilled jobs are in danger of becoming obsolete.‚Äù The winner‚Äôs defence Midjourney typically creates a number of versions using the prompts and users choose the best outcomes. Allen reportedly had hundreds of iterations of which he chose the top three, and printed them on canvas. According to reports, he submitted it in the digital art category under the name ‚ÄúJason M Allen via Midjourney‚Äù, which meant that he had disclosed the nature of the artwork to the judges. Furthermore, as The New York Times reported, the category‚Äôs rules allow any ‚Äúartistic practice that uses digital technology as part of the creative or presentation process.‚Äù This could mean that using AI programs to create art is no different from using other software such as Photoshop. The judges, however, were unaware that Midjourney was an AI program but went on to state that they would have declared Allen as the winner even if they had. Many believe that the increasing popularity of AI-based will lead to the creation of a separate category that keeps it distinct from other forms of digital art.

This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.New home for world-renowned artist's sculpture1 / 22><NOWNew home for world-renowned artist's sculptureInternational¬†search¬†underway¬†for¬†missing¬†art.mp4Farmers' plan to cull rising number of kangaroosNew scam targeting senior QueenslandersExclusive look at Qantas' new AirbusUrgent warning over deadly synthetic drugMediSecure hack investigation handed over to federal policeNew claims about alleged Russian spy revealedWoman dragged by dog in vicious attackHundreds of weapons seized in Sydney raidsMajor IT outage wipes out businesses systems globallyGlobal tech outage impacting businesses across the countryPolice investigate suspicious fire at Gold Coast luxury car rental businessHundreds of weapons seized in SydneyThree businesses destroyed after arson attack in MelbourneFormer pilot Greg Lynn will appeal murder convictionThousands of rare bird eggs seized in TasmaniaWoman charged with trespass after refusing to leave PM's electorate officeWoman fleeced of $50,000 in Telstra scamPerth crash victim's family campaign for road safetyCFMEU South Australia face claims of ‚Äòbullying, threats, intimidation‚ÄôMan allegedly assaults pro-Palestine group in hotel Tweet  Facebook  Mail Jason M Allen was almost too nervous to enter his first art competition. Now, his award-winning image is sparking controversy about whether art can be generated by a computer, and what, exactly, it means to be an artist.In August, Allen, a game designer who lives in Pueblo West, Colorado, won first place in the emerging artist division's "digital arts/digitally manipulated photography" category at the Colorado State Fair Fine Arts Competition.His winning image, titled Th√©√¢tre D'op√©ra Spatial (French for Space Opera Theatre), was made with Midjourney ‚Äî an artificial intelligence system that can produce detailed images when fed written prompts. A US$300 ($440) prize accompanied his win.READ MORE: RBA tipped for 'super-sized' cash rate increase as cost of living crisis bitesIn August, Jason M Allen won first place in the emerging artist division's "digital arts/digitally manipulated photography" category at the Colorado State Fair Fine Arts Competition. (Courtesy Jason M Allen) (Courtesy Jason M Allen)"I'm fascinated by this imagery. I love it. And it think everyone should see it," Allen, 39, told CNN Business in an interview on Friday.Allen's winning image looks like a bright, surreal cross between a Renaissance and steampunk painting. It's one of three such images he entered in the competition. In total, 11 people entered 18 pieces of art in the same category in the emerging artist division.The definition for the category in which Allen competed states that digital art refers to works that use "digital technology as part of the creative or presentation process". Allen stated that Midjourney was used to create his image when he entered the contest, he said.



YOU MAY ALSO LIKE

Recommended by

 



Midjourney is one of a growing number of such AI image generators ‚Äî others include Google Research's Imagen and OpenAI's DALL-E 2. Anyone can use Midjourney via Discord, while DALL-E 2 requires an invitation, and Imagen has not been opened up to users outside Google.READ MORE: Melbourne mural criticised as 'utterly offensive' to Ukrainians
The newness of these tools, how they're used to produce images, and, in some cases, the gatekeeping for access to some of the most powerful ones has led to debates about whether they can truly make art or assist humans in making art.This came into sharp focus for Allen not long after his win. Allen had posted excitedly about his win on Midjourney's Discord server on August 25, along with pictures of his three entries; it went viral on Twitter days later, with many artists angered by Allen's win because of his use of AI to create the image, as a story by Vice's Motherboard reported earlier this week."This sucks for the exact same reason we don't let robots participate in the Olympics," one Twitter user wrote.
"This is the literal definition of 'pressed a few buttons to make a digital art piece'," another Tweeted."AI artwork is the 'banana taped to the wall' of the digital world now."Yet while Allen didn't use a paintbrush to create his winning piece, there was plenty of work involved, he said."It's not like you're just smashing words together and winning competitions," he said.You can feed a phrase like "an oil painting of an angry strawberry" to Midjourney and receive several images from the AI system within seconds but Allen's process wasn't that simple. To get the final three images he entered in the competition, he said, took more than 80 hours.First, he said, he played around with phrasing that led Midjourney to generate images of women in frilly dresses and space helmets ‚Äî he was trying to mash up Victorian-style costuming with space themes, he said.Over time, with many slight tweaks to his written prompt (such as to adjust lighting and colour harmony), he created 900 iterations of what led to his final three images.He cleaned up those three images in Photoshop, such as by giving one of the female figures in his winning image a head with wavy, dark hair after Midjourney had rendered her headless.Then he ran the images through another software program called Gigapixel AI that can improve resolution and had the images printed on canvas at a local print shop.Allen is glad the debate over whether AI can be used to make art is capturing so much attention."Rather than hating on the technology or the people behind it, we need to recognise that it's a powerful tool and use it for good so we can all move forward rather than sulking about it," Allen said.Cal Duran, an artist and art teacher who was one of the judges for the competition, said that while Allen's piece included a mention of Midjourney, he didn't realise that it was generated by AI when judging it. Still, he sticks by his decision to award it first place in its category, he said, calling it a "beautiful piece".Near-complete dinosaur skeleton sells for 10 times predictionView Gallery"I think there's a lot involved in this piece and I think the AI technology may give more opportunities to people who may not find themselves artists in the conventional way," he said.Allen won't yet say what the text prompt was behind his winning image ‚Äî he's planning to keep it a secret until he publishes a larger related work that he hopes will be finished later this year.Continue readingArtificial IntelligenceartsTechcompetitionWorldUSACONTACT USSend your stories to contact@9news.com.auProperty News: Watch as the ocean creeps in to swallow this waterfront mansion.

Title: Intel ups its game in Artificial Intelligence; takes it to Indian schools - The Financial Express
description: As per the company, the curriculum designed for AI for future workforce is technical.

headline: Intel ups its game in Artificial Intelligence; takes it to Indian schools
name: Financial Express
article text: MPSOS Ruk Jana Nahi 10th, 12th Result 2024 Highlights: MP State Open School result to be out on mpsos.nic.in soon ‚Äì Check details here
articleBody: As Artificial Intelligence (AI) becomes more mainstream, technology companies such as Intel seems to latched on to the trend. Intel plans to launch several initiatives such as 'AI for future workforce' and 'AI for current workforce' by the end of this year with an aim to build skill-ready workforce, Shweta Khurana, senior director ‚Äì Asia Pacific and Japan (APJ), government partnerships and initiatives, global government affairs, Intel told FE Education Online. ‚ÄúAI for future workforce will cater to 18 years and above and AI for current workforce is for professionals with primary focus on women driven small and medium enterprises (SMEs),‚Äù Khurana said. The programme will be delivered virtually by an Intel certified coach. As per the company, the curriculum designed for AI for future workforce is technical; however; students does not require any prior domain knowledge. Furthermore, projects under the programme are focussed on industrial impacts such as common trade application, predictive maintenance, viral post protection, insurance fraud protection among others. ‚ÄúThrough virtual training in a real-world environment for three months learners will be exposed to the challenges, and how to build solutions for the same,‚Äù Khurana added. Earlier initiatives from Intel included Intel AI for youth, Responsible AI for Youth and Building AI Readiness among Young Innovators. Under these three initiatives, over 3,50,000 students have been trained with AI skills since 2019. Under Intel AI for youth programmes the learners acquire technical skills in data science, computer vision and natural language processes as well as social skills focused on AI ethics and biases and AI solutions-building. For this, Intel has collaborated with the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), and the Ministry of Education (MoE) and AI curriculum for students, setting up focused AI skill labs, and creation of AI-readiness by skilling facilitators in CBSE schools. Responsible AI for youth initiative empowers government school students between eight to 12th grade with a new-age technology mindset, relevant skill sets, and access to required tools. Intel has collaborated with the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MEitY), Government of India (GoI), National e-Governance Division (NeGD), to launch this programme. In July 2021, Intel launched the AI For All initiative in collaboration with the MoE  with the purpose of creating a basic understanding of AI for everyone in India. AI For All is a four hour, self-paced learning program that demystifies AI in an inclusive manner. It is applicable to a student or a stay-at-home parent, a professional in any field or even a senior citizen. The programme is aimed to demystify AI for one million Indian citizens in its first year. Furthermore, in March 2022, Intel joined hands with the Department of Science and Technology (DST), GoI for its programme ‚ÄòBuilding AI Readiness among Young Innovators‚Äô that aims to build digital readiness among students between six to 10 grade enrolled under DST‚Äôs INSPIRE ‚Äì Awards MANAK scheme. The programme aims to build an AI-ready generation to empower students with the knowledge and skills to leverage AI in an inclusive way.
